fields.name: Quality of Explanation of Content
fields.description: Applies to objects designed to explain content. Used to rate how thoroughly subject matter is explained or otherwise revealed in resource. Teachers might use object with whole class, small group, or individual student. Students might use this object to self-tutor.

fields.name: Utility of Materials as Tools to Teach Others
fields.description: Applies to objects designed as an instructional tool to teach others. Primary user would be teacher looking for classroom tools. Rubric is useful for a variety of object types, including units, lessons, applets.

fields.name: Quality of Assessments
fields.description: Applies to objects that seek to determine what a student knows before, during, or after a topic is taught. When many assessments are included in one object, the rubric is applied to the entire set.

fields.name: Degree of Interactivity
fields.description: Applies to objects that have a designed interactive component. Used to rate degree and quality of an object’s interactivity. Interactivity broadly means that the object responds to the user – the object behaves differently based on what the user does.

fields.name: Quality of Practice Exercises
fields.description: Applies to objects that contain collections or sets of practice exercises to help students better understand information or solidify skills and knowledge by doing tasks that routinize skills and procedures. Typically a collection or pool of practice exercises is treated as a single object and the rubric is applied to the set.

fields.name: Opportunities for Deeper Learning
fields.description: Applies to objects that engage learners to: think critically; make sense of complex problems and persevere in solving them; reason abstractly; construct viable arguments and critique the reasoning of others; construct, use, or analyze models; look for and express regularity in repeated reasoning; work collaboratively with others; learn how to learn; apply discrete knowledge and skills to real-world situations.  Use this rubric for math objects that advance mastery of academic content as well as critical thinking, reasoning, and collaboration.

All are true: Provides comprehensive information so effectively that target audience can easily understand the content; connects the content with important associated concepts; does not need to be augmented with additional explanation or materials; big ideas are identified and consolidated in the object for the learners, regardless of method.

Content is explained in a way that makes skills, procedures, concepts, and/or information understandable. It falls short of superior in that it does not make the important connections between and among the various aspects clear.

An object is rated as having limited value for content explanation if the content is correctly explained, but is very limited. This is a cursory treatment of the content that is not developed enough to serve someone attempting to learn the content for the first time. The explanations are not thorough enough to serve as more than a review for most learners.

An object is rated as having very weak or no value for content explanation if its explanations are confusing or contain errors.  In its present form, there is little likelihood that this object will contribute to understanding.

This rubric is not applicable for an object that is not designed to explain content (e.g. a sheet of mathematical formulae, a map). It may be possible to apply the object in some way that aids a learner’s understanding, but that is beyond any obvious or described purpose of the object.

All are true: Materials and ideas are comprehensive, easy-to-understand and use to teach others; includes suggestions for use with a variety of learners; all components are provided and work as intended, including estimate of planning time and materials list; facilitate mixed instructional approaches for larger objects.

Comprehensive, easy-to-understand and easy-to-use unit or lesson designed to teach others. Falls short of Superior because either: 1) object does not include suggestions for ways to use materials with variety of learners, or 2) core components are underdeveloped in the object.

Includes a useful approach or idea to teach an important topic but falls short of Strong because either: 1) the object is missing important elements, e.g. directions for some parts of a lesson are not included or 2) important elements do not do what they should, e.g. directions are unclear. Teachers would need to supplement this object to use it effectively.
Confusing, contains errors, is missing many important elements. Not useful in its present form.

This rubric is *not applicable* for an object that is not designed as a teacher’s instructional tool.  An enterprising educator may find an application for such an object during a lesson, but that would be an unintended use.

All are true: all skills/knowledge assessed align clearly to content and performance expectations; everything assessed is included in the object’s material (unless identified as an extension); the most important aspects of expectations are targeted and given appropriate weight/attention; multiple assessment modes are offered; level of difficulty is a result of the complexity of the subject-area and level of cognitive demand, rather than unrelated issues (e.g. complex vocabulary).

An object is rated as having a *strong* assessment if it assesses all or nearly all of the content and performance expectations intended, but requires a level of cognitive demand or analysis that does not match the stated assessment goals. One or more assessment modes may be offered—selected response, long and short constructed response, or individual and group work.
Assesses much of the content or performance expectations intended, as stated or implicit in the object, but omits some important content or performance expectations.

An object is rated as having very weak assessments if it contains significant errors, does not assess important content or performance, or is written in a way that is confusing to students. These are not the only reasons an assessment may fall short, but are illustrations of the type of objects that fall into this category.

This rubric is deemed *not applicable* for an object that is not designed to have an assessment component. Even though one might imagine how aspects ways aspects of this object could be used for assessment purposes, not applicable is the appropriate score.

All are true: responsive to student input in a way the creates an individualized learning experience (adapts to the learner based on what s/he does, or allows flexibility or individual control during the learning experience); interactive element is purposeful and directly related to learning; well-designed and easy-to-use, encouraging learner use; appears to function flawlessly on the expected platform.

The object has an interactive feature that is purposeful and directly related to learning, even if it does not provide an individualized learning experience. Like superior objects, strong interactive objects must be well designed, easy-to-use, and function flawlessly on the expected platform.

Interactive element neither relates to nor detracts from learning. This kind of interactive element (e.g., earning points or achieving levels for correct answers) might be designed to increase student motivation and to build content understanding by rewarding or entertaining the learner and extending the time the user engages with the content.

An object is rated as having *very weak* or no value for interactivity if it has interactive features that are poorly conceived and/or executed.  The interactive features might fail to operate as intended, or the “bells and whistles” distract the user or unnecessarily take up user time (e.g. every correct answer results in dozens of cart-wheeling clowns filling the page).
Does not contain an interactive element.

All are true: offers an extensive number (e.g. 25 or more) of practice exercises that support mastery of content and performance expectations; exercises are clearly written and supported by accurate answer keys; there are a variety of exercise types and/or the exercises are available in a variety of formats, as appropriate (e.g. short/long/extended response, multiple choice).

Meets at least one of three criteria: 1) offers many (e.g. 10-20) well-written exercises aligned to the content and performance expectations and supported by accurate answer keys, 2) there are a variety of exercise types, or 3) the exercises are available in a variety of formats, as appropriate to the exercise type.
Includes only a few well-written exercises with little variation in format or type.

Exercises do not cover content and performance expectations, errors in the answer key, lacks an answer key, or is unsound for another reason. (OER with only one or two practice exercises should be scored N/A.)

This rubric is *not applicable* to an object that is not designed to provide learner practice. Even though one might imagine ways it could be used is this way, *not applicable* is the appropriate score. In general, an OER with only one or two practice exercises should be scored *N/A* rather than *very weak*.

**All** are true: **three** or more of the practices are required; offers a range of cognitive demand appropriate to and supportive of material targeted; appropriate scaffolding and direction is provided or available.
**One** or **two**, perhaps co-mingled, practices are included, such as an object that requires abstract reasoning skills **and** perseverance to reach a solution.
Contains a complex problem, but is missing clear guidance on how to tap into various aspects of deeper learning.

Based on poorly formulated problems and/or unclear directions. The likelihood that this unit or lesson will lead to things like sense-making, abstract reasoning, constructing arguments or modeling is very low. The object appears to be intended to provide some of the deeper learning opportunities listed in the list of descriptors for this rubric, but it is not useful in its present form.

This rubric is *not applicable* to an object that does not appear to be designed to provide the opportunity for deeper learning. Even though one might imagine how it could be used to do this, *not applicable* is the appropriate score.

**All** are true: object is completely aligned to all content and performance expectations in the standard; no elements in the object are extraneous to the standard; all elements of the standard are completely addressed.

Strong alignment is indicated for one of two reasons: 1) covers all but minor elements of the standard, cluster or domain *or* 2) covers slightly more than the standard without differentiating between the required versus optional material.
Limited alignment is indicated if the object addresses only part (either content or performance) of the identified standard, cluster or domain, as long as there is fidelity to the part it covers.

An object has *very weak* alignment for either one of two reasons: 1) the object does not match the intended standards or 2) the object matches only to minimally important aspects of a standard, cluster or domain. These objects will not typically be useful for instruction of core concepts and performances covered by the standard.

This rubric is not applicable for an object that has not had standards suggested for alignment. For example, the rubric might not be applicable to a set of raw data. This rubric is also not applicable if the initial alignment suggestion work is not yet completed.
